entry.title: Optimizing Accessibility for Cognitive Disabilities
entry.content:
Millions of people struggle with focus, memory, and processing complex information every day. In fact, the World Health Organization reports that one in three people worldwide lives with a neurological condition that can affect cognitive function [1]. While these challenges can be permanent for some, designing for people with cognitive disabilities benefits everyone. It helps anyone dealing with temporary or situational challenges that impact their ability to focus, such as trying to complete a task when fatigued or under high emotional stress, or simply trying to learn something new in a noisy, crowded environment.

A smiling woman with long hair and glasses, wearing a headset, sits in front of a computer. Text reads: "1 in 3 people worldwide live with a neurological condition that can affect cognitive functioning. SAP designs for neurodivergent people. Check out our tips for wayfinding and orientation, motion content and more!

Design for Accessibility is Design for Everyone

When we design with accessibility in mind, we’re not just checking a box, we’re creating digital experiences that are easier to use for everyone. Making interfaces clear, predictable, and easy to navigate doesn’t just help some users; it makes products better across the board.

5 Tips to Optimize Accessibility for Those with Cognitive Disabilities

Supporting users with cognitive disabilities means creating clear, predictable interfaces that support diverse ways of thinking and processing information. The guidance in SAP’s Accessibility Design Tools, Second Edition, and the Inclusive Research Handbook helps turn this awareness into practical steps. With these resources in mind, here are five tips to help you get started:

1. Prioritize Clarity

  • Prioritize clarity with plain language, simple sentences, and familiar terms.
  • Reinforce meaning visually and verbally by using clear labels and pairing icons with text.
  • Why? Unclear instructions or unfamiliar icons can cause confusion, which can lead to errors or task abandonment.

2. Help users understand their location

  • Help users understand their location by keeping important details, like task summaries or form labels, consistently visible.
  • Use fixed headers or status indicators so users don’t lose track of their place in a process.
  • Why? Users might forget the context, instructions, or earlier steps in a task, which can lead to errors or incomplete tasks.

3. Design clean, simple interfaces

  • Design clean, simple interfaces with a clear visual hierarchy.
  • Group related content together and reduce visual noise.
  • For potentially distracting elements like animations or background sounds, provide clear and easy-to-find controls so users can pause, stop, or hide them.
  • Why? Unexpected motion or sounds and visual clutter can be overwhelming for people with cognitive and sensory disabilities, making it hard to concentrate and possibly experience anxiety. Giving users direct control allows them to create a customized space that fits their needs, improving comfort and helping them stay on task.

4. Maintain a predictable experience

  • Maintain consistent navigation, layout, and terminology to ensure a predictable experience.
  • Use progressive disclosure and clearly announce changes in advance — for example, through banners or tooltips.
  • Why? Inconsistent patterns and sudden changes can be stressful and confusing. A predictable interface helps users build mental models and navigate with confidence, which can reduce anxiety and increase task focus.

5. Break tasks into simple steps

  • Break tasks into small, simple, manageable steps.
  • Use visual aids like progress bars, checklists, and grouped content to clarify the structure.
  • Include clear instructions, plain language, familiar icons, and specific feedback messages.
  • Why? A disorganized or complex interface can increase cognitive load, making it harder to stay focused, remember previous steps, and track progress. Clear structure and communication reduce overwhelm and help users complete tasks more confidently. 

How SAP Designs with Accessibility in Mind

Technology keeps changing, but our commitment to Accessibility remains constant. We're focused on ensuring innovation moves forward without leaving anyone behind. To achieve that goal, we are actively innovating how accessibility considerations can be integrated in all parts of the Product Development Lifecycle, especially in early phases like design.

Want to dig deeper? Explore SAP's Accessibility Design Tools, Second Edition

References:

1. World Health Organization. (2024, March 14). Over 1 in 3 people affected by neurological conditions, the leading cause of illness and disability worldwide.

entry.title: SAP Improvement 2H 2025 - impact for Proxy rights on supported tools
entry.content:
On 2H 2025 release, SAP referred in the following KBA https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3667810 that using proxy rights to access below tools will be non-supported:

Modules that Don't Support Proxy AccessModuleWas supported before 2H 2025?

SAP SuccessFactors Learning

No

Note: Before 2H 2025 there was a Learning proxy module option, but it wasn’t functioning. After 2H 2025, the Learning option is no longer available.

SAP SuccessFactors Platform

Yes

Note: The following features and tools have stopped supporting Proxy access:
  • Configuration Transport Center
  • Instance Refresh
  • Integration Center
  • Security Center
  • Proxy Management
  • Proxy Import
  • Security Permission Reports
  • Manage RBP Admin and Super Admin Access
  • Privacy Statement in user settings
  • Reset Password in user settings

The change of proxy access in supported and non-supported tools has an huge impact on customers current Proxy usage.

Customers have already requested in the following SAP Improvement 
https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/359099/?section=sectionDetails - "Return back the permission to access to the Integration Center under the proxy" to not proceed with this changes or rethink the deliver until 2H 2025 is delivered in production in November 2025.

If this is delivered in 2H 2025 then there are huge impact in customers such has:
- being able to use proxy to troubleshoot issues related to the listed tools;
-being able to proxy technical users to schedule and run IC jobs;
- Being able to proxy SUPERADMIN user in case of emergency and not able to access the tools listed;
- Not able to proxy Technical users and preform any RBP access management;
- Processes defined by customers impacted due to system behavior over proxy.

Customers are not able to opt-out this system behavior.

This deliver should be reconsidered, we suggest customers vote on the SAP Improvement mentioned in order to raise concern over this 2H 2025 automatically on change for the release.

entry.title: Re: The workflow event trace is active but doesn't trace anything (transactions SWELS/SWEL)
entry.content:
The screen of SWELS is badly designed, it shows that it's active but in fact it may be inactive according to the time range defined in the restriction, which by default makes the trace valid during one hour after the activation. After this delay, the field "Event trace switched on" remains active.

It's very disturbing.

This behavior is explained in the note 2498410 - SWEL doesn't capture event even though the event was raised - SAP for Me.

So, remember, don't trust the "active" flag, always check the restrictions.

Also, if you're working extensively with the trace, go to the restrictions and define a much bigger interval (till the end of the day for instance):

NB: if you really don't like this restriction feature and want to rely only on the "active" flag of the initial screen, you may ignore the restrictions by entering a huge time range:

entry.title: Syncing Hiring manager back with position in Onboarding
entry.content:
Hi,

We have a scenario where we are defaulting the Manager's Manager (HM+) to the Hiring Manager operator field in RCM. We then map Hiring Manager to Manager ID field in Job Info in Recruit to Hire Mapping.

However, we are noticing that in ONB the Manager ID field is not being updated with the actual manager of the position and is keeping the mapped value (HM+). Our expectation was that based on position / job sync rules and position management settings, this would be populated with the correct manager but SAP has indicated this is not expected behavior.

Has anyone encountered this or found a way to populate this on initiation of ONB correctly? We do not have New Hire Data Review enabled so new hire tasks like welcome message are being assigned to the wrong user. 

Note: SAP indicated we could not use a business rule in Job Info because Job Info is not visible during Personal Data Collection, so rules will not be executed

Looking for any recommendations or workaround.

POST https://localhost:50000/b1s/v1/IncomingPayments(123)/Cancel

I've tried including different fields in the request body, such as:

Is there any supported way to control the posting date of the cancellation entry in SAP B1?

entry.title: Re: Merit Calculation Based on Different Current Salary
entry.content:
Hi @MariaCarlotaAbreu 

Ideally you'd want to get them to use one and only pay component group so they can stay standard config-wise. Usually these requirements come from unique processes that they know are not right but they're still trying to put them into the system when in reality transitioning to new HR cloud solution should be when they readjust all this. I would flag this request as high-risk and bring it to the project managers for discussions with stakeholders at a higher level than the comp team.

Anyways to come back to your issue, not sure Compounding will work here. 

Here is something that would work:

  1. Create an MDF object with an Evaluate rule on it that says "If employee is in this country A, then set MDF decimal field "Current Salary" to use PCG value, if employee is in country B, set it to the PC value."
  2. Create an integration center job to feed this MDF with userID for all employees (there are demos in some of my previous blogs like here or here).
  3. Add a custom field on your Comp template with ID = meritTarget and map it to the MDF custom field "Current Salary".
        <comp-field-definition id="meritTarget" isCustomField="true" isVisible="true" hideInProfile="false" hideInForm="false" type="money" alignment="center" useFor="salary" readOnly="true" width="6" hidePercentage="false" hideAmount="false" percentageReadOnly="false" reloadable="false" auditable="false" displayOrder="14" reportable="true" needCalcTotal="false">
          <comp-field-label><![CDATA[Current Salary]]></comp-field-label>
        </comp-field-definition>

 

  1. Then go to your XML and change the code to be Target in this tag. 

If you have other recommendation columns they would need a similar setup, but unfortunately we can only do that on merit, lumpsum and lumpsum2. For lumpsum and lumpsum2 you would first need to add lumpsumTarget and lumpsum2Target fields from Design Worksheet then map them to the MDF field Current Salary directly in Design Worksheet.

If the customer wants to have another recommendation column than merit impact the final salary (for example extra), you have two options: use one of the lumpsumTarget or lumpsum2Target and have final salary fields designed as custom fields (vs standard ones). Or keep extra but make it Percentage only and calculate the amount based on the meritTarget column like this : ((extra/curSalary)/100)*meritTarget

All the best,

Xavier

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public cloud 的開窗可以隱藏不需要的公司代碼嗎?
entry.content:
Hello @Fang,

Thank you for the question. In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the proper way to prevent users from seeing or using the CN company code is to restrict access to it in their business settings roles.

Maintain Business Roles → Preserve Restrictions and Organisational Values

For each relevant role, configure the company Code as Restricted for Read, Write, and Value Help, and include only the company codes that users are authorised to access your TW codes. This restricts data access and, in current releases, also limits the options available in many value help picklists. SAP Help Portal-Maintain Business Roles

Recent changes assist with hiding in picklists

From release 2508, SAP introduced support for Company Code restrictions in Value Help dialogues, improving how Value Help enforces role restrictions. If you are on or after 2508, users’ F4 lists will more accurately reflect the restricted company codes you assign.  SAP Help Portal-Company Code Restriction for Value Help Dialogues

Optional User default settings for convenience only

Set each user’s Default Company Code to their TW code to ensure the correct value is automatically filled. This complements role restrictions but does not replace them. SAP Help Portal-Maintaining Your Default User Values

Notes: In earlier versions, the value help for Company Code was not always limited they could display all codes even if access was restricted at posting/view time. If you still observe that behaviour, it’s consistent with earlier guidance; the 2508 enhancement addresses it. SAP Support Portal-3356685 - S/4HANA Cloud : Restrictions on Company Code(M_RECH_BUK)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How correct data on completed I-9 Form and E-Verify i...
entry.content:
Hi @JulieMcSwain ,

The person responsible for reviewing the TNC should select the option that New Hire information provided in the FAN is Incorrect. In our case, the employee entered the wrong SSN, so the option mentions correcting the new hire's form I-9 Section 1, but the exact text displayed for this option may be different depending on the error.

That will close the existing E-Verify case. The next step needs to be done by a user with permission to create a Trigger I-9 Flow in Manage Data (in our case, this is our IT admins). 

Go to Manage Data - Create New - Trigger I-9 Flow.

  • User: Search for the employee by name or username and select the name in the drop down once it appears
  • Trigger Type: I-9 Reverification, Correct Form I-9 Section 1 Data, or Correct Form I-9 Section 2 Data
  • Process: the 32-character alphanumeric string that appears at the end of the URL when you open that employee's record within the Onboarding dashboard
  • Save

This will create a task in the dashboard for the employee or the employer representative (depending on the Trigger Type you selected. In your case, Section 2 would go to the manager, HR, or responsible user depending on your configuration).

Hope this helps! 

Heather

entry.title: Separate “Tips” line under Restaurant category in SAP Fiori Expense Entry
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m currently working on the configuration of SAP Fiori for Travel & Expense reporting and I have a question regarding how to handle tips (gratuities) in the Restaurant expense category.

We would like users to be able to enter their restaurant expenses and the tips on two separate lines, but still under the same main category — for example:

Restaurant: 100 (Meal)
                       20 (Tips)

The goal is to have separate totals for meals and tips, while keeping both entries linked to the overall “Restaurant” category.

Does anyone know if:

  • there is a standard field or configuration option in Fiori that allows this (e.g., a separate “Tips” field under Restaurant), or

  • if it’s necessary to create a new subcategory or expense type (like “Restaurant – Tips”) to achieve this separation?

We’re on S/4HANA (Fiori environment), and ideally, I’d like to stay within standard functionality if possible — avoiding custom development unless really required.

Thanks a lot in advance for your insights and best practices!

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: SAC Numeric Point - How to show last year same day value
entry.content:
@Fiona_ 

Lookup also has a previous Year variation as below. You could try the below.

LOOKUP([Sales], [d/Date] = Previous("Year", 1))

If you are facing an issue with Leap Year handling you could try something like this.

A Year is leap year if its  perfectly divisible by 4, 100 and 400 respectively. So create 2 versions of your lookup one with 365 and another for 366 days lookback.

NLP = LOOKUP([Sales], [d/Date] = Previous("Day", 365)) // For Non Leap

LP= LOOKUP([Sales], [d/Date] = Previous("Day", 366))  // For Leap

Then a final calculated measure based on checking the leap year check

IF(MOD(TONUMBER([d/Date].[p/YEAR]), 4)=0 AND MOD(TONUMBER([d/Date].[p/YEAR]), 100)=0 AND
MOD(TONUMBER([d/Date].[p/YEAR]), 400)=0
,[LP],[NLP])

 

Hope this helps or gives you some idea to ponder.

Nikhil

entry.title: Guidance Needed on Linking RFC Function Module Table to Entity Set in OData Service
entry.content:
I have created an OData service using the Import → RFC option, and the mapping has been successfully completed with the relevant RFC Function Module. I would now like to understand how to link the Function Module's table (/IWBEP/I_SBD_DS) to a specific Entity Set table (/IWBEP/I_SBO_ES).

Could someone please guide me on how to achieve this?

Written select query:

SELECT a~function_name
INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_table)
FROM /iwbep/i_sbd_ds AS a
JOIN /iwbep/i_sbo_es AS b
ON a~project = b~project
AND a~node_uuid = b~node_uuid
WHERE b~project = 'ZTEST'
AND b~name = 'testSet'.

entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports RAS VerifyDatabase can't find an unkn...
entry.content:
Hi Patrick,

I've been thinking about your request more and I don't see this happening, R&D adding the same Macro it uses in CRD into the SDK.

If you have or get a support contract you can submit an Enhancement Request here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/identity-provisioning/identity-provisioning/submitting-improvement-requests?locale=en-US

All I can suggest is you will need to build this feature yourself.

As you know the RPT file retains the "image" of the data structure within the file, getting to it you can use various API's including the code below I use to get the Tables Links.

What you should be able to do is log into the DB, compare the SQL statement to what CRD is using and then do the logic to compare.

Here's how to get the SQL, must set the log on info first, you can then compare the SQL or run it against MS SQL and see if it reports an error and then interpret that MS error.

NOTE: you do need to try/catch a lot of this, for example if the Report uses a Stored Procedure you must set the parameters first, same if the report uses a CR Command.

Below code gets the SQL from the report:

if (ConWorks || crDatabase.Tables.Count == 0)
{
    // test if no main report DB then go to subreport logon
    if (crDatabase.Tables.Count != 0)
    {
        //gp.FromString("2-0");
        GroupPath gp = new GroupPath();
        string tmp = String.Empty;
        try
        {
            rptClientDoc.RowsetController.GetSQLStatement(gp, out tmp);
            btnSQLStatement.Text = tmp;
            btnSQLStatement.AppendText("\n");
        }
        catch (Exception ex)
        {
            if (ex.Message == "Fetching SQL statements is not supported for this report.")
            {
                CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.Controllers.DatabaseController databaseController = rpt.ReportClientDocument.DatabaseController;
                ISCRTable oldTable = (ISCRTable)databaseController.Database.Tables[0];

                if (nvp2.Name.ToString() == crConnectioninfo.DatabaseName.ToString())
                {
                    if (((dynamic)oldTable).CommandText.ToString() != null)
                    {
                        btnSQLStatement.Text += "Main Report Command: " + ((dynamic)oldTable).CommandText.ToString();
                        btnSQLStatement.Text += "\n";
                    }
                }
                else
                {
                    btnSQLStatement.Text += "\nEither Wrong log on Server Name: Database: " + nvp2.Value.ToString() + " does not exist\n";
                    btnSQLStatement.Text += "\nTable Name is: " + oldTable.QualifiedName.ToString() + "\n";
                }
            }
            else
            {
                if (ex.Message == "Missing parameter values.")
                {
                    // set parameter values
                    //ReportDocumentSetParameters(rpt);
                }
                else
                    btnSQLStatement.Text = "ERROR: " + ex.Message;
                //return;
            }
        }
    }...

 Hope that helps...

entry.title: Re: Automatically plan production order after component a...
entry.content:
Good day @Jakobstrom 

Thank you for your question.

The following references provide more details.

Manage Production Orders

Situation Template

Make to Stock (Discrete Industries)

To summarise, in public cloud, you can only automatically adjust production order through rescheduling or re-planning based on material/component availability. Direct automatic date shifts after Available-to-Promise check are not supported as in on-premise custom exits but you can achieve similar behaviour through the following standard functions:

1. Component Availability Check and Rescheduling Proposal:

  • When you run the Availability Check from your production order, the system calculates component availability dates.
  • If it detects shortages, the Reschedule Proposal shows earliest possible start dates.
  • You can manually accept the proposal to update the order basic dates.

 2. Material Requirements Planning based on scheduling

  • Planned orders already consider lead times and component availability when MRP runs with correct parameters.
  • This ensures realistic basic dates are calculated upon order creation.
  • Due to the clean core restriction in public cloud, automatic rescheduling of production orders after ATP is not allowed through custom code.

 3. Situation Handling for Component Delays

  • You can enable the situation template “Component Delay in Production Order” so that if any component’s confirmed date is later thatn the order start date, you will get notified to adjust or reschedule the order.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Add functional currency in VAT report
entry.content:
Hello @Tina_Hellgren 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, VAT reporting apps show values solely in the company code currency. The traditional GUI feature Alternative Local Currency accessed via transaction S_ALR_87012357 – Advance Return on Sales/Purchase Tax is not accessible and cannot be enabled in the cloud environment.

If your company reports in EUR as its functional currency, you have two supported options.

Use Output Control → Read Foreign Currency
In the Create Advance Return for Sales/Purchase Tax app, select the Read Foreign Currency option in Output Control and add the foreign-currency columns to the Additional List layout. This displays amounts in the additional currency, like the legacy behaviour.

 

Build a custom analytical report
Create a Custom CDS View or Custom Analytical Query on I_JournalEntryItem, including:

    • AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency (Local Currency)
    • AmountInGroupCurrency (your EUR functional currency)
      Filter by VAT-relevant tax codes or G/L accounts to generate a management-level VAT reconciliation in both SEK and EUR.

Please note that statutory VAT filing remains based on the local currency; the EUR display is for internal reporting only.

SAP Help Portal – Define Currency Types and Assign to Ledgers

SAP Help Portal – Advance Return for Sales/Purchase Tax (Public Cloud)

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Factory Calendar Special Rules - CDS View or API
entry.content:
Hello @GAK1 

Thank you for your question.

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, no released CDS View or API directly exposes Factory Calendar → Special Rules date from-to, workday flag, text. These are reflected internally in the working-day pattern but not as a dataset.

You can instead use the following released views and approach:

CDS View I_FACTORYCALENDAR – provides factory calendar IDs, validity, and descriptions.

CDS View I_FACTORYCALWorkingDaysPerYr – returns encoded working-day patterns per year/month, which already consider any special rules.

Join this data with I_CalendarDate to derive a daily IsWorkingDay indicator if you need day-level results.

If external access is required, build a Custom CDS View on top of these released views and expose it as an OData API through a custom communication scenario.

In the public cloud, traditional tables like TFAIN/TFAIT and transactions used in on-premises systems are unavailable.
Check  SAP Help Portal – Factory Calendar in S/4HANA Cloud and the Released VDM Views documentation for I_FACTORYCALENDAR

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Bank Statement not completed
entry.content:
Hello @panagiotism 

Thank you for your question.

In your case and based on your description, I think what is happening is when you import a bank statement, the posting logic uses Posting Area 1 for the main bank entry and Posting Area 2 for clearing open item. Which is consistent with the public cloud.

If Vendor open item is already cleared as is in your case, the system still expects Area 2 to find and clear an open item. Therefore, the statement remains Not Completed because the clearing logic cannot find a match.

In public cloud, you cannot modify the posting rules or disable Posting Area 2 due to the clean core restrictions SAP introduced in that edition.

In public cloud edition, you cannot skip Posting Area 2 in the posting rule but you can make the bank statement complete by ensuring that:

  • The external transaction type used in the bank account master matches one that is configured without an open-item clearing requirement, or
  • The system recognises the item as external transaction completed through reconciliation processing. This will ensure that Posting Area 2 is automatically marked as complete.

To summarise:

Posting Rule F010 expects you to have an open item for Posting Area 2, but your item was already cleard.

The restrictions in public cloud hinder some modifications due to Clean Core approach.

Your solution options are:

  1. To create a Processing Rule to mark as completed when no open items exists.
  2. Or manually mark statement as completed in Manage Bank Statements.
  3. For future automation, ensure your external transaction mapping in Manage Bank Accounts are correct.

The following references provide more details.

Manage Bank Statements

Overview on Automatic Bank Statement Processing

Manage Processing Rules for Bank Statements

Cash and Liquidity Management

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Limitation in Service Quotation Handling in SAP S/4HA...
entry.content:
Hello @Lasse96 ,

You’ve run into current design limits of Service Quotation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition:

SAP’s FAQ states you can’t delete an accepted service quotation due to a follow-up service order. The app also doesn’t allow deletions of open quotations, so the standard way to undo is to reject them, optionally letting it expire. SAP Community-Service Quotation in S/4Hana Service - Frequently Asked Questions

Sold-To Party change: For Service Quotations in Public Cloud, the Sold-To is not changeable after creation. Attempts to modify partner changeability through SSCUIs result in the same partner-procedure error you indicated; SAP considers this expected behavior.

Copy as template: Use Reference works, but keep original partner determination, suitable only for the same Sold-To. For a different customer, SAP recommends rejecting the incorrect one and creating a new quotation for the correct Sold-To. (See: rejection handling and  learning content.) SAP Learning-Explaining the Service Quotation Process Steps

Useful SAP Documentation

  • Microlearning: Using Rejection Reasons in Service Quotations and Orders. SAP Learning
  • FAQ (Service Quotation): Deletion/acceptance behaviour and recommended handling. SAP Community
  • KBA 3324390: Sold-To is not editable when copying if partner procedure flags it non-changeable. SAP Support Portal
  • Partner determination (help/overview): Background on how partner changeability is controlled by procedure. SAP Help Portal

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Manage Landed Costs / Additional Costs Functionality...
entry.content:
Hi @cblikeem 

Thank you for your question.

There is no Manage Landed Costs Fiori app in public cloud edition. That name appears in on-prem/private cloud discussions, it isn’t a standard public cloud app today.

However, if standard clean core is adhered to, you can capture freight, customs, insurance, etc. When set up correctly, you can capitalise them into inventory value through standard delivery costs in Purchasing and Invoicing:

  • Planned delivery costs on the PO à Posted to a delivery-cost clearing account at GR/IV and distributed to the material when the supplier/freight invoices are posted.
  • Unplanned delivery costs on the supplier invoice à can be distributed to PO items so that inventory value is adjusted (This is subject to valuation settings).
  • Multiple vendors are supported by using separate invoices that settle the delivery-cost clearing.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Delivery Costs (Planned and Unplanned)

Create Supplier Invoice with Purchase Order

Direct Procurement, Reconcile GR/IR Accounts: Business Background

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Why Is the Test Execution on my Test Plan remain 0% a...
entry.content:
Hello @oquijano0327 

This behaviour usually happens when the automated process runs without a bound Test Data Container (TDC) variant or without valid test-user authentication. The Executed: “Without Test Data Conta...” message in your log confirms that the test launched without an active data variant, so no steps could execute

Please check the following points

Ensure a TDC variant is bound and used. Add the TDC to the test process or plan, and select the variant as the default. If a run begins “without TDC,” steps will not be parameterised, and you will see “Executed: Without Test Data Container.” SAP Help-Test Your Progress-Add Test Data Container to Test Plan

Validate test user, login to Manage Test User. Plans stuck at 0% commonly trace to wrong or stale credentials for the test user. Re-enter a known-good password (or switch to SSO) and re-run. SAP Support Portal-2820953 - Automatic test processes start, but no progress

If you use an external IdP. You should configure Conditional Authentication in Test Your Processes; otherwise, runs stay at 0%. SAP Help Portal-Configure Test Your Processes

Authorisations, ensure admin/tester has SAP_BR_ADMIN_TEST_AUTOMATION from Maintain Business Roles; without it, key TAT functions are blocked. SAP Support Portal-3111932 - Missing role SAP_BR_ADMIN_TEST_AUTOMATION in Maintain Business Role app

In 'Manage Your Test Processes', open 4HH automate and confirm each step has an Automated Script (some tenants/plans miss synced content, so nothing runs). Refresh content and re-add the process if needed. SAP Help Portal-About the Application

General stuck at 0%” troubleshooting, SAP KBAs list these exact symptoms and recommend re-checking credentials, roles, and rerunning after fixing settings. SAP Support Portal-3087418 - Test Plan execution is not progressing or stuck at 0%

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Error connecting interfaces with FACe (Spain)
entry.content:
Hello @MatiasGarciaKPS 

Thank you for sharing the details and screenshot.

The XML is valid as FACe accepts it when uploaded manually, so the issue lies in the connection, trust, or authorisation between SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite, and Face. The server error points to a communication problem in the iFlow, not content mapping.

The Spain FACe content is provided as an SAP Integration Suite package named “SAP Document and Reporting Compliance: Electronic Invoicing of Public Entities for Spain.” You need to copy, configure, and deploy its iFlows (Send/Status/Cancel) SAP API Hub/SAP Document and Reporting Compliance: Electronic Invoicing of Public Entities for Spain

Find the concrete setup PDFs on SAP Business Accelerator Hub, which include step-by-step instructions for copying the package, setting endpoints, and security material. SAP API Hub

Pinpoint errors in Integration Suite Monitor → Message Processing. This is the primary place to see the exact HTTP/TLS/auth failure that produced the CXF {faultcode}server symptom. SAP Help Portal/SAP Integration Suite/Monitor Message Processing

Certificate/trust issues (PKIX path) are a common cause of CXF “server” faults. SAP’s notes and community guidance confirm that missing/incorrect root or intermediate certificates in the tenant keystore lead to PKIX/handshake failures. SAP Support Portal/2874258 - Error "sun.security.validator.ValidatorException: PKIX path building failed" occurs testing the connection of a SOAP web service datastore - SAP Cloud Platform Integration for Data Services

S/4HANA Cloud side: validate the Communication Arrangement that points to your Integration Suite runtime and use the Connectivity Trace if needed (handy for SSL handshake/login problems). SAP Help Portal/Communication Arrangements

Product area reference: Spain electronic documents under Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC). SAP Help Portal-Spain-Document and Reporting Compliance

Your initial diagnosis is correct: because FACe accepts your XML files when uploaded manually, the issue probably resides in the transport connection (endpoint, authentication, or certificates) between S/4HANA Cloud and Face through the Integration Suite. Use the Message Processing monitor to pinpoint the specific error, then modify the endpoint, credentials, or keystore trust chain according to the Spain package guide.

Let me know if you need further assistance

Chuma

GenAI-Assisted Content (sources: SAP Help & SAP Business Accelerator Hub).

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order -Order confirmation Interface Failing
entry.content:
Good day @Rkmandal 

The issue you are facing isn’t with configuration or authorization but with locking and sequencing. You cannot change cloud locking behaviour (Clean Core) but you can prevent the conflict through CPI message serialisation or delayed retries.

In summary, when you send Order Confirmations from a 3rd-party system to public cloud through SAP CPI, you may get the user Inbound error. This happens because the same user used in the communication arrangement is still locking the purchase order while another message tries to update it. That means:

  • Two confirmations arriving at the same time for the same PO
  • CPI retries too quickly before the previous message is finished

Although you can’t change the locking logic in public cloud, you can solve it from the CPI side by:

  1. Configuring your iFlow to process messages one after another per PO number
  2. Adding a short 15-30 second delay in the exception flow before CPI retries.
  3. Splitting integration load by using different technical users if you process many Pos in parallel.

Here are references for more information.

User already processing the purchasing document "XXX"

Purchase Order Confirmations

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Request for validation of S/4HANA Data Migration Stra...
entry.content:
Good day @S0026934150 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, your overall Data Migration Strategy is well-structured and closely aligned with SAP’s recommended approach for phases S/4HANA rollouts. Below are a few validation points and best-practice confirmations for key areas you raised.

1. You are making use of SAP BODS for your ETL. This is validated and also recommended because that is the preferred ETL tool for complex S4/HANA migration programs, especially when you have high-volume master and transactional data, you need data profiling and enrichments capabilities, you need traceability and auditability across production loads, etc.

  • Best practices are combining the migration cockpit with SAP Advanced Data Migration or SAP Data Service for target uploads.
  • Ensure your BODS-to-S/4 integration ends with standardized load templates.

 2. The use of Master Data Synchronisation between ECC and S/4HANA is partially recommended. Rather use selective synchronisation. Make sure you avoid continuous, full bi-directional synchronisation. Instead maintain controlled synchronisation for master data that are shared across rollouts.

  • SAP recommends using SAP MDG or central data governance layer for harmonisation rather than one-off technical interfaces.
  • If MDG is not yet in place, restrict synchronisation to read-only reference replication through IDocs or API to prevent dual maintenance errors.

 3. Implementing MDG is considered best practice, especially if you have a multi-entity rollouts. It ensures: Central governance and approval workflow for master data creation, A reliable record for each master data object across geographies & Provides consistency and reduce deduplication effort in later load cycles.

  • Use MDG for key domains like Business Partner, Material Master, and Finance Master Data.
  • Integrate MDG output directly with S/4HANA through SOA services or IDoc replication to ensure synchronisation integrity.

 4. Qualification and Validation for Mock and Production Loads are compliant with the SAP methodology. Your plan to conduct at least two mock load cycles is consistent with SAP’s Activate and Data Migration Factory standards.

  • The final production load must have full traceability.
  • For high-volume domains, ensure incremental data load testing to avoid performance bottlenecks.

 5. Overall strategy aligns well, however, consider the following aspects:

  • Consider integration SAP Data Intelligence for metadata management and lineage tracking, especially if multiple sources exist.
  • Introduce a Central Data Migration Factory approach for cross-region large rollouts.
  • Document data ownership, sign-off workflows, and cutover sequencing in your final plan to align with the Quality Gate framework.

 

Consult these references for more details.

SAP Activate Methodology Workstreams Names update

Data Migration

SAP Master Data Governance

Handling Data Migration Content

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Managing Large Investment Projects with SAP Investment Management
entry.content:
Large investment projects are complex and resource-intensive. They require careful planning, budgeting, monitoring, and control to ensure successful execution. These projects play a vital role in a company’s growth, financial stability, and operational efficiency. To manage them effectively, organizations need a structured and integrated digital solution.

SAP Investment Management (IM) provides a comprehensive framework to manage capital investments efficiently. The module integrates seamlessly with other SAP components such as Project System (PS) and Asset Accounting (AA), enabling end-to-end visibility and control over capital expenditures.

This blog highlights a three-part series of papers that together explain the full capabilities of the SAP Investment Management module:

  • Part 1 – Configuration of the Investment Program and Appropriation Requests (Requesting Measures)
  • Part 2 – Setup of Investment Measures (WBS or Internal order) and the Settlement Process
  • Part 3 – Step-by-step execution process for managing large-scale capital investments

By combining insights from all three papers, this blog serves as a complete guide to SAP Investment Management, offering practical knowledge for finance, project management, and SAP professionals seeking to improve how they plan and control large investment projects.

INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT IN SAP: A KEY TOOL FOR MANAGING LARGE EXPENDITURES

Investment Management (IM) is a key module in SAP that helps organizations plan, monitor, and control major spending initiatives. These expenditures can be capital-related, such as investments in infrastructure, machinery, or technology, or non-capital, including R&D, acquisitions, or major maintenance projects.

The IM module allows companies to design their own investment program structure based on business needs, consolidating all approved and planned costs into a hierarchical framework. Using requesting measures, such as Appropriation Requests, organizations can plan long-term investments that often span several years in line with project lifecycles.

SAP IM also incorporates workflow-based approvals, ensuring strong governance and compliance throughout the investment process. While IM focuses on planning and budgeting, effective investment lifecycle management also requires linking it with Investment Measures, the operational side of managing project costs and asset creation.

Investment Measures (WBS or Internal order) in SAP are the objects that receive budgets, track planned versus actual costs, and settle expenses to fixed assets, cost centers, or general ledger (G/L) accounts. Depending on the investment type, these measures may take the form of WBS (Work Breakdown Structure) elements or internal orders.

In essence, SAP Investment Management brings together four key components, which work seamlessly to ensure accurate, transparent, and efficient management of capital and non-capital investments. The following section explores these components in more detail.

STEPS IN MANAGING LARGE EXPENDITURES IN SAP INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT

Fig 1: SAP Investment Management Overview

Source: SAP Help Portal on Investment Management (Overview) 

  1. Requesting Measures (Appropriation Request): Similar to a purchase requisition, an appropriation request is used to request approval for large expenditures. This request contains critical details about the project, including the planned costs. A standard SAP workflow is set up to ensure that appropriation requests are reviewed and approved before any funds are committed.
  2. Investment Program: The investment program provides a hierarchical structure within the organization to plan, budget, and distribute large expenditures. The program allows the organization to define its own structure based on needs. All approved planned costs for requesting measures are aggregated within this hierarchy. Costs are planned from the bottom up, while budgets are allocated from the top down. Investment measures can only be assigned to the lowest level in the hierarchy, called "end nodes," which can include internal orders, WBS elements, or maintenance orders.
  3. Investment Measure: Investment measures are used to track the planned budget and actual spend. These can be Project System (WBS) elements or Internal Orders. Investment measures receive the budget allocated from the investment program and track the actual expenditure as it occurs. It tightly controls the spending by monitoring the planning, budgeting, actual, commitment, and remaining available funds. Investment measures are closely linked with the Asset Accounting module in SAP, ensuring that any unallocated spending at period-end is properly settled into assets under construction (AUC).
  4. Settlement planning and settlement: Once a project or investment measure is completed or partially completed, it must be settled. A project can be settled to various objects, such as fixed assets, cost centers, other investment measures, or general ledger accounts. The settlement process requires careful planning to determine how funds will be allocated (e.g., by percentage, amount, or proportion). Once the project is ready to settle, the settlement rules are defined in the investment measure to transfer the financial information to the appropriate accounts..

The whole design of implementing and end-to-end execution investment management in SAP is divided into 3 papers as below. These papers are free to download and use:

Paper 1: Laying the Foundation: Structuring Investment Programs and Approval Request— A Guide to Initiating and Organizing Capital Investments

This paper covers the initial steps in managing large projects through SAP Investment Management, including the setting up of investment programs and the process for requesting measures. The paper can be downloaded from the link below:

 Part 1 – Configuration of the Investment Program and Appropriation Requests (Requesting Measures)

 Paper 2: From Planning to Action: Configuring Investment Measures and Settlement Processes — Ensuring Control and Accountability in Capital Projects

This paper focuses on configuring investment measures and defining settlement rules, providing the foundation for effective planning, tracking, and accountability in capital project execution. The paper can be downloaded from the link below:

Part 2 – Setup of Investment Measures (WBS or Internal order) and the Settlement Process

Paper 3: Executing Large Investments: A Step-by-Step Guide to Project Delivery and Oversight— Managing the Full Lifecycle of Strategic Expenditures

The final paper outlines the end-to-end execution process for managing large-scale investments using SAP, including project tracking, monitoring, and lifecycle management. The complete end-to-end Investment Management execution process in SAP includes the following five key steps:

  1. Establishing the Investment Program Structure.
  2. Initiating Investment Plans through Appropriation Requests.
  3. Building Project System Hierarchy.
  4. Cost Planning and Budgeting.
  5. Executing and Settling the Project.

The paper can be downloaded from the link below: 

Part 3 – Step-by-step execution process for managing large-scale capital investments

Conclusion

Effectively managing large capital investments is vital for an organization’s financial health and long-term success. In this three-part series on SAP’s Investment Management (IM) paper, we’ve presented a complete framework for planning, executing, and settling large-scale expenditures in a structured and efficient way.

  • Paper 1 laid the foundation by configuring investment programs and requesting measures, establishing a clear structure for tracking planned spending.
  • Paper 2 focused on designing investment measures and settlement rules, enabling organizations to monitor and control project execution throughout the investment lifecycle.
  • Paper 3 demonstrates the end-to-end execution process of large capital projects, from master data setup to project execution and final settlement.

By following this integrated approach, organizations can confidently manage investments, keeping projects on budget, meeting deadlines, and aligning with strategic objectives. SAP’s IM module helps navigate the complexities of capital investment management, optimizing financial operations and supporting both short-term and long-term business goals.

Together, these three papers provide a step-by-step guide to managing strategic investments, giving businesses the clarity, control, and insight needed to ensure success in their capital projects.

entry.title: Re: SAC Numeric Point - How to show last year same day value
entry.content:
@N1kh1l 

Thank you so much for your reply—your input has really sparked some new ideas, and I’m truly grateful for that!

But if you don’t mind, I still have a few more questions to ask. I know I can use LOOKUP([Sales], [d/Date] = Previous("Year", 1)), but it seems to return the total for the entire previous year rather than breaking it down to the daily level. Since I need to see the figures for each specific day, I haven’t gone with this "previous year" method.

Also, when I count back 365 or 366 days to map LP/NLP values, I can’t just rely on the year alone to do it simply. Take 2024 and 2025 as an example: for any date on or before February 28, 2025, I need to subtract 366 days to get the corresponding value from the previous year. But for dates after March 1, 2025, I have to subtract 365 days instead—otherwise, the value from February 29, 2024, would end up incorrectly mapped to March 1, 2025.   So in a scenario like this, do I have to add some month-specific conditions to the IF statement to perfectly align the LP and NLP values? This approach feels a bit cumbersome, and I’m curious if there’s a more efficient way to handle it.

entry.title: Vibe Coding a Mobile App to display Business Partners
entry.content:
Last week I posted about the release of the MCP server for mobile development kit. In that post, I’ve provided details about the setup and offered some simple use cases as examples. In this post, I will be using the Cursor coding agent together with the MCP server for mobile development kit to vibe code a mobile app from scratch.

We are going to create a simple mobile app that shows a list of Business Partners. The sample data is stored in an S/4HANA Cloud instance made available through SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

It is important to note that while Cursor is featured in this example, SAP is evaluating several coding agents to ensure broad compatibility with our MCP server. This demonstration does not imply preference or endorsement of any particular product.

Picking a data source from SAP Business Accelerator Hub

We start with opening SAP Business Accelerator Hub and browsing to the Business Partner API overview. This is an API available on the S/4HANA Cloud Public Editor. We are going to use this API for our mobile app. To set up the connection in SAP Mobile Services, we need to gather some information.

Select Show API Key and copy the key.

In the Configuration Details tab, you will find the SANDBOX URL. Copy this URL.

Configuring the mobile app in the SAP Mobile Services Admin cockpit

Assuming you have an instance of SAP Mobile Services available in your SAP BTP subaccount, open the Mobile Services Admin cockpit.  You can do this via Service Marketplace, select Mobile Services and open the Support link. There is no need to create an instance here.

If you don’t have the service yet, simply add the Mobile Services entitlement to your subaccount. If you’ve created a brand-new subaccount, then make sure to enable Cloud Foundry, add the Cloud Foundry Runtime entitlement and allocate some runtime memory (1 unit is sufficient). You will also need an active Cloud Foundry space.

In the Mobile Services Admin cockpit, navigate to the Mobile Applications > Native/MDK tab and click New. Select Mobile Development Kit (MDK) as the type of application. Click Next.

Provide details about the app.

Click Next and leave the remaining configuration steps unchanged. Select Finish after reviewing the selections.

Once the app definition is created, select Connectivity.

We will now set up a connection to the data service we’ve found in SAP Business Accelerator Hub. We first provide information about the Destination Name and Destination Type (Internet Destination).

For the URL, paste the URL you’ve copied from SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Click Next.

Create a custom header called apikey and paste the API key you’ve obtained from Business Accelerator Hub into the Header Value field.

For the remaining steps, leave all settings as default and click Next and finally Finish.

Access your Cloud Foundry environment

To be able to exchange information between your (local) development environment and your SAP Mobile Services instance, you need to log in to your BTP environment on Cloud Foundry. Make sure you have installed the Cloud Foundry CLI.

The easiest way to log in is to use the following command and follow the instructions to open the provided url:

cf  login <your target endpoint> --sso

Your target endpoint is visible on the Overview page of your BTP subaccount.

 

Using Cursor

Configuring the coding agent

We’ll open Cursor, where we have configured the mdk-mcp server. Detailed instructions can be found at https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/mdk-mcp-server . For Cursor, you'll find the MCP servers in the Cursor Settings > Tools & MCP. You can enable or disable MCP servers as needed. My recommendation is to only enable those MCP servers that are needed to perform a specific tasks. Having too many tools active could confuse the agent and LLM.

Retrieving the mobile application details

For our project, we need to collect information about the mobile app definition and mobile destination we've created earlier. Go to the Command Palette and open “MDK: Open Mobile Application Editor”

 

The Mobile Application editor opens. Select the application we’ve created in SAP Mobile Services and tick the box of the destination.

By clicking “Add App to Project”, we collect all relevant information into a file named “.service.metadata”. This information will be used to create the mobile application project in the next steps.

Let’s get mobile vibe coding!

We are now ready to start creating the mobile application. We type the following prompt in the agent’s chat pane:

Create a mobile application to browse the list of Business Partners. 
Besides updating the generated README.md file, do not create documentation.
Make sure there are no linting errors and validate the project.

Note: I’ve specifically mentioned to skip creating documentation. This is because this agent, combined with Claude Sonnet 4.5, is very keen on creating documentation. Although this is a good practice, it can cause issues with bundling our metadata. There is also no need to ‘burn’ more tokens than necessary.

After a few iterations, the application and README.md file has been created.

To test what has been generated so far, we will deploy the application to SAP Mobile Services.

Open a new chat and enter the prompt

Deploy the application

Based on the information retrieved from the MCP server, the agent will trigger a deployment to SAP Mobile Services and show a QR code that we can use for onboarding the SAP Mobile Services client application. This client can be downloaded from the App Store and Google Play.

 

The mobile app looks like this on iPhone:

 

The app runs fine. However, the partner list shows mainly record id numbers. We also notice this number get repeated in the list. Can we change this without touching any of the code or metadata? You don’t need to be an MDK expert to enhance the app. Your agent can help!

We use the following prompts:

Change the Business Partners list to show their name and search term 
instead of business partner id and customer id.
Change the subhead to BusinessPartnerGrouping.
On the list page, change the title to “Business Partner Overview”

The main page also looks like we are pulling the information straight out of a database. Let’s fix that.

On the main page, change the title to My Business Partners, 
change the "vibe_coded_demoapp" text to "Vibe coding showcase", 
change "A_BusinessPartner" to "Show list of Business Partners"

The level of detail on the page varies based on the agent and LLM; sometimes it's very detailed, while smarter agents produce more compact pages. In my example, there's too much information for mobile viewing.

To make the detail page more compact, please remove the 
relationship sections (to_<name>) and reduce the visible fields.
On the detail page, change the title to "Business Partner Details"

The object header on the detail page could look a bit better if we change the contents.
 

On the detail page, change the title to "Business Partner Details" 
and in the object header, please show the following items: 

headline = full name
subhead = id
BodyText = organization name
footnote = search item
Description = form of address
Status text = is blocked
substatus text = category

After the agent makes the changes, the resulting app is deployed and looks a bit a better:

 

We can ask the agent to review the app and make it look even better. For this use case, I’ve provided screenshots of the main page, the list page and the detail page and prompted:

Can you make the main/list/detail page look more professional

After several iterations, and reminding the agent to consult the MDK documentation, we have an app the indeed looks better. For the main page, I’ve also asked to add an image with the SAP logo.


Short summary of the changes made for each page:

  • Main page
    • Added branding footer toolbar
    • Added logo image
    • Improved button design
    • Added welcome section
    • Added brief key features overview
  • List page
    • Circular avatars
    • Blue accent color
    • Improved search bar
  • Detail page
    • Cleaner object header
    • Split the long list into logical sections
    • Improved layout
    • Better visual hierarchy

 

Thoughts

For those unfamiliar with MDK and the tools we provide, it might look like magic to create a mobile app like this one. However, before the arrival of coding agents we already offered generators that offered scaffolding. The AI coding agent makes use of the same tools to create the app. What has changed is that instead of the developer continuing to enhance the project manually, it is now the coding assistant doing most of these changes based on the prompts provided by the developer.

In some cases, I’ve noticed the agent makes wrong assumptions and does not consult the information made available through the MCP server. An example of this is regarding the CSS styling. The agent assumed full support for CSS styling, like available in modern HTML5-based web apps. However, MDK offers limited support for styling. Without checking the documentation, the agent created styles that had no effect. I had to remind the agent to check the documentation first (maybe we should create a rule for this).

Practical recommendation: It is better to start every task in a separate chat with your agent to keep the context window small. This will help creating better results and less hallucinations.

Conclusion

Developing a mobile app based on Mobile Development Kit is now faster and easier thanks to AI coding agents. By introducing the MCP server for mobile development kit, we ensure coding agents can tap into knowledge and best practices that LLMs have not been trained on (yet).

Depending on the coding agent and LLM used, your results may vary. The development still needs supervision. Always review what the coding agent produces and make adjustments where needed.

As always, feedback is welcome.
